title: Train Whistle
description: For this project, I needed to create a train whistle using a block of wood and a 2" x 4" x 8" wooden dowel using various woodworking equipment.

timeline.heading: Safety Tests
timeline.description: In order to operate the machines, I needed to complete the safety trainings on https://www.iteea-safety.org/index.htm to make sure I stay safe while operating these machines. I successfully completed all the training videos and tests, as shown left.

timeline.heading: Cutting the Mouthpiece
timeline.description:
To start off, I chopped off 5/8" of the end of the wooden block using a miter saw. This was my second time attempt since during a previous attempt, I accidently stopped the miter saw while it was in contact with the wood, causing the mouthpiece to fly off and hit the blade, damaging the mouthpiece.

Afterwards, I used a drill press to drill out the top cavity cutout with a 1 1/8" Forstner bit.

timeline.heading: Drilling the Resonance Holes
timeline.description: To drill out the resonance holes, I marked the location of the holes with a pencil and used a drill press to drill the holes. I used a 3/8" drill bit for each holes. I drilled 4 holes of depth 2 3/4", 3 1/4", 3 7/8", and 4 1/2".

timeline.heading: Cutting the Side Cavities
timeline.description: To cut the cavities, I marked the borders of them using a pencil and ruler and cut the lines using a band saw by placing the wooden block on a 45 degree angle.

timeline.heading: Placing the Reeds
timeline.description: For the reeds, I used a belt sander to flatten the edge of the reed and used a scroll saw to cut the reeds into 4, 2 inch pieces. I placed the reeds into each resonance hole and adjusted them to allow for optimal sound. Afterwards, I used woodglue to glue each rod in and used a miter saw to cut off the excess.

timeline.heading: Final Result
timeline.description:
I glued the mouthpiece from earlier onto the top to finish this whistle off. I gave it a test blow and it sounded like an actual train whistle.

Overall, this project was successful since I managed to create a functional train whistle and learned a lot about woodworking in the process. In this project, I learned how to use the miter saw, the drill press, the band saw, the band sander, and the scroll saw. I also learned to stop the machine after it stops touching the material as learned by my first attempt. I think in future projects, I could add little indents where a drill bit will first come in contact since when drilling, I noticed the drill bit sliding a little bit, causing the holes to get misaligned. Another consideration is finding a better way to hold the wooden block while drilling since finding a good way to properly and securely hold the block was challenging.

Overall, I grew a lot as a person since I now have experience and familarity with woodworking in general, opening me up to considering woodworking as an option in future projects. I could use these skills to help improve the esthetics of my projects if I wanted it to be displayed in a visible location.
